pull_request.title: [Blueprint] Add support for moving and rotating models

pullrequest.title: [Blueprint] Add support for moving and rotating models

content.raw:
The idea of having the world name in some services is to support two worlds side-by-side in the future. So we could have 2 scenes.

But when it comes to moving objects with a mouse, since the user only has one mouse, they won't be manipulating these 2 at the same time. So I think it's a good idea to use a single generic service, and both scenes would respond to the same transform control.
content.html:
The idea of having the world name in some services is to support two worlds side-by-side in the future. So we could have 2 scenes.

But when it comes to moving objects with a mouse, since the user only has one mouse, they won't be manipulating these 2 at the same time. So I think it's a good idea to use a single generic service, and both scenes would respond to the same transform control.

content.raw:
I tried porting that to ign-gazebo while reviewing pull request #296 in branch [ign_tool_cmake](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/branch/ign_tool_cmake), but it still doesn't work. The main difference with ign-gazebo, is that it doesn't link to the main library; it links to the `ign` component library, and for some reason `Fiddle` isn't able to dlopen this library.

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64&build=1549)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1549/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1549/
content.html:
I tried porting that to ign-gazebo while reviewing pull request #296 in branch ign_tool_cmake, but it still doesn't work. The main difference with ign-gazebo, is that it doesn't link to the main library; it links to the ign component library, and for some reason Fiddle isn't able to dlopen this library.

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1549/

content.raw:
I see a jump with a model like this:


```
    <include>
      <name>rescue_randy_1</name>
      <uri>
        https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/1.0/openrobotics/models/Rescue Randy Sitting
      </uri>
      <pose>1 1 1 0.138212 0 1.759210</pose>
    </include>
```

I added the above to `shapes.sdf`, and then translated the model up. After mouse release, the model jumped up vertically.

Do you see this?

      <pose>1 1 1 0.138212 0 1.759210</pose>

content.raw:
Yeah I think the long-term plan is to have an editing mode separate from simulation. But I think we also spoke about the usefulness of supporting at least some commands during simulation, like applying force and teleporting, because these are helpful while debugging (think of moving a model in front of a robot for it to follow).

I can disable it while playing for now, but I think the quickest solution would be to keep the classic behaviour. For disabling to work nicely we should also disable the buttons.
content.html:
Yeah I think the long-term plan is to have an editing mode separate from simulation. But I think we also spoke about the usefulness of supporting at least some commands during simulation, like applying force and teleporting, because these are helpful while debugging (think of moving a model in front of a robot for it to follow).

I can disable it while playing for now, but I think the quickest solution would be to keep the classic behaviour. For disabling to work nicely we should also disable the buttons.

content.raw: Yup, I believe this is the same concern as @nkoenig 's. I'll go with the 2nd option to match the classic behaviour. It should also be mentioned that on classic, the model is semi-transparent while being dragged so it's a bit clearer that the poses are not sent to the server until the button is released (see [this issue](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1802/make-models-semi-transparent-while-being)).
content.html: Yup, I believe this is the same concern as @nkoenig 's. I'll go with the 2nd option to match the classic behaviour. It should also be mentioned that on classic, the model is semi-transparent while being dragged so it's a bit clearer that the poses are not sent to the server until the button is released (see this issue).

pullrequest.title: [Blueprint] Add support for moving and rotating models

content.raw:
So this somewhat fixes it but it now has a different behavior. As soon as I release the mouse, the model's pose is sent to physics and the simulation continues from that pose, but what's shown on the scene doesn't reflect the new poses of the model. For example, if I translate a model vertically and release the mouse, the model starts falling in physics, but it remains at rest at in the scene at the translated position. When I finally select arrow mode the model's pose in the scene is instantaneously changed. I think we have two options here:

* The new pose of the model is not sent to physics until we exit transform mode. Entering on a new transform mode, i.e, switching from translate to rotate, is not considered exiting transform mode. Clicking on a new object while still in transform mode is not considered exiting transform mode.
* The new pose of the model is sent to physics as soon as the mouse is released. The pose of the "active" model and its gizmo should be updated with poses from physics. I believe this is the behavior of Gazebo classic.
content.html:
So this somewhat fixes it but it now has a different behavior. As soon as I release the mouse, the model's pose is sent to physics and the simulation continues from that pose, but what's shown on the scene doesn't reflect the new poses of the model. For example, if I translate a model vertically and release the mouse, the model starts falling in physics, but it remains at rest at in the scene at the translated position. When I finally select arrow mode the model's pose in the scene is instantaneously changed. I think we have two options here:

  • The new pose of the model is not sent to physics until we exit transform mode. Entering on a new transform mode, i.e, switching from translate to rotate, is not considered exiting transform mode. Clicking on a new object while still in transform mode is not considered exiting transform mode.
  • The new pose of the model is sent to physics as soon as the mouse is released. The pose of the "active" model and its gizmo should be updated with poses from physics. I believe this is the behavior of Gazebo classic.
